question: Question_B_02_(b)
sols:
Recall from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B2_(a)}{part
(a)} that we figured out that the general solution was

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}(t)=c_1
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-t)
+ c_2
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).\end{align*}

With the initial condition

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix},\end{align*}

we can find the constants $c_1$ and $c_2$ for this particular problem.
Plugging in the initial condition we get,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}(0)=c_1
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(0)
+ c_2
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
c_1+2c_2\\
2c_1+3c_2
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}

Therefore we conclude that,

\begin{align*}\left\{\begin{aligned}
c_1+2c_2&=1\\
2c_1+3c_2&=1
\end{aligned}\right.\end{align*}

which has solution, $c_1=-1$ and $c_2=1$. Therefore the solution to this
problem with initial condition

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}(0)=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

is

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}(t)=-
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-t)
+ 
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).\end{align*}
